title: Salmon Pan-Cooking Temperature Tips (Stainless Steel)

items.name: Pan surface temperature
items.details: Should be around 400-425F. Set stove to medium-high, not medium.

items.name: Oil readiness test
items.details: Oil should be shimmering and just barely starting to smoke. If it sits there looking calm, the pan is too cold.

items.name: Stainless steel preheat
items.details: Let the empty pan heat 2-3 full minutes on medium-high before adding oil. Stainless holds heat well once hot but heats up slower than nonstick.

items.name: Sear technique
items.details: Lay salmon in away from you. Should hear an immediate confident sizzle. Do not move the salmon early - it will release on its own once the crust forms (usually 3-4 minutes skin-side down).

items.name: Internal temperature to remove
items.details: Pull salmon off at 120-125F internal (measured at thickest part). It will coast up to 130-135F while resting.

items.name: Temperature guide
items.details: 120-125F = medium, best texture. 130-135F = fully done but still good. 140F+ = dry, avoid.

notes: Salmon forgives nothing once overcooked. Pull it early and let carryover cooking finish the job. Stainless steel requires more aggressive preheating than nonstick pans.
